text:
Whether you need a disguise to run from the
law or are just trying to emulate *NSYNC-era

frosted tips, you may need some chemical assistance
to put that hue in your do.
So, calling all bottle blondes and box brunettes!

Get ready to learn everything you’re dyeing
to know about the chemistry of artificial
hair color.

Human beings around the world have colored
their hair since ancient times with vinegar,
nutshells, berries and even lead—yikes.

The story of salon hair color really has its
roots in the history of modern chemistry.

In 1907, French chemist Eugène Schueller
marketed an artificial hair color formulation

using para-phenylenediamine, or PPD, a compound
still used in some hair dyes today.

In fact, Schueller’s company, the French
Harmless Hair Dye Co., later became known
as L’Oreal.

To understand how today’s hair color works,
we’ll need to review some basic hair anatomy—and
no, I’m not talking about the mullet.

Each strand of hair grows from a hair follicle,
a surprisingly complex organ complete with

an arrector pili muscle that gives us goosebumps
and a sebaceous gland that secretes oil.

But all of that is what lies beneath the skin’s
surface.

The visible part of hair—ya know the stuff
you brush, braid, fade or pull into a man
bun—is known as the hair shaft.

The shaft is covered by a layer of overlapping
keratin cells called the cuticle, which protect
and waterproof the inner layers of the hair.

Non-permanent dyes that come in sprays and
gels coat the cuticle but usually fade after
a few shampoos.

To get that color to permanently last, we
need to penetrate that cuticle and allow dye

to reach an inner layer of the hair shaft
called the cortex.

The cortex contains more keratin plus important
pigment proteins called melanins, which give
hair its natural color.

To make this happen, salons bring out the
big guns.

That means developer—a fancy salon term
for hydrogen peroxide—mixed into a solution

containing chemicals called primary intermediates,
coupling compounds, or “couplers., and ammonia.

When the mixture is applied to hair, the ammonia
is responsible for some of those signature

nostril-tingling scents of hair dye and is
also extremely basic.
Like... platinum ombré on Stacy basic.

With a PH of over 11, the solution causes
the entire hair shaft to swell.

This separates the keratin cells that make
up the cuticle and allows the dye molecules
to seep into the cortex.
And now, for the mane event.

As our mixture penetrates the tens of thousands
of hair shafts on your head, hydrogen peroxide

lightens the natural pigment and takes away
electrons from, or oxidizes, the dye’s “primary
intermediate” compounds.

These chemicals, like Schueller’s PPD give
off colorful reactive species when oxidized

—not unlike how iron turns red when it oxidizes
to rust.

Darker hair colors are achieved by using a
higher concentration of primary intermediates,

while lighter dyes let hydrogen peroxide do
most of the work.

But whether you’re a summer, a winter or
are going all in for a cosplay, the primary

intermediates also react with the dye’s
“couplers” to fine tune and achieve that
perfect shade.

There are dozens of coupling compounds that
can alter the exact tone But we’re not gonna

split hairs here, most are alcohols and amines
that interact with primary intermediates to
produce large, complex dye molecules.

Dye companies usually mix and match couplers
to achieve the intended tint and tone.

Think of them like Bob Ross adding a happy
little highlight to your luscious locks.
And as a hair icon, he should know.

Once the ammonia is washed out, the cuticle
cells fall back in place and the dye molecules

are locked in—leaving you with a glorious
head of permanent color.

Unfortunately, as the ammonia leaves the hair
and the keratin layer reforms, the scaly cells
may not fit together as neatly as before.

This spells damage for your hair fibers, and
you might notice your locks are a bit more
fragile.

Swapping ammonia for alternative alkaline
agents like ethanolamine may help prevent

some of this damage, but they may also limit
the hues you can choose.

Dyed hair can also be prone to dullness between
touch-ups—primarily because free radical

oxygens left behind in the dying process or
even released by the induction of the sun’s

UV rays can degrade your new pigment and the
hair cuticle itself.

To fight this, some color-protecting shampoos
contain antioxidants to help clear the free
radicals and help keep that shine.

To keep that coif gram-worthy, you might also
want to avoid chemicals that can shift your
new hue.

For example, blondes will want to steer clear
of copper—often used as an anti-algae compound

in swimming pools—which can oxidize their
pigment to create a green tint.

Yeah, I’m afraid that patina looks a lot
cuter on the Statue of Liberty.
Want more?

We also get into the hairy details of shunning
shampoo and explain why redheads may be more
sensitive to pain.

Thanks for watching, and be sure to like and
subscribe on your way out.
See you next week.
